facts.text: Two rival factions in Mill area, Nagpur: appellant Khushal and Tukaram (acquitted by High Court) leaders of one faction; Ramgopal PW4, Inayatullah PW1, Tantu PW5 leaders of opposite faction.
Prior incidents between factions; Inayatullah and Tantu prosecuted for some.
On February 12, 1956, Tantu and Inayatullah made reports of attacks by Khushal's party.
Sampat lodged report at 9:30pm on February 12, 1956 at Ganeshpeth PS against Inayatullah alias Kalia and Tantu for attack with sharp-edged weapons (Ex P-26).
Appellant Khushal on bad terms with deceased Baboolal, who was friendly with opposite faction leaders.
Pre-meditated murder of Baboolal by Khushal, Sampat, Mahadeo, Tukaram with swords and spears in narrow lane at 9pm on February 12, 1956.
Baboolal taken to Mayo hospital, arrived 9:25pm.
Dying declaration to Dr. Kanikdale PW14 at 9:25pm (Ex P-17): assaulted by Khushal and Tukaram with swords and spears.
Doctor telephoned Ganeshpeth PS at 9:45pm; SI A.K. Khan recorded FIR Ex P-1, registered u/s 307 IPC.
SI recorded dying declaration Ex P-2 at 10:15pm after consulting Dr. Ingle who advised magistrate but SI proceeded.
Magistrate M.S. Khetkar recorded dying declaration Ex P-16 between 11:15-11:35pm; Dr. Ingle certified fit state of mind.
Khushal arrested on February 16, 1956 in locked out-house on Seminary Hill.
Tukaram arrested later; both accused of absconding.
Sessions Trial No. 34/1956: First Additional District Judge Nagpur convicted Khushal u/s 302 IPC (death), Tukaram u/s 302/34 (life), acquitted Sampat and Mahadeo; dated July 10, 1956.

High Court (Nagpur): Criminal Appeal 205/1956, Ref 15/1956, Govt appeal, revision: Acquitted Tukaram (doubt on caste Teli vs Kolhi, multiple Tukarams), upheld Khushal conviction/death, acquitted others; dated October 15, 1956. Local inspection Sept 17, 1956.
High Court rejected eyewitnesses Inayatullah PW1, Sadashiv PW3 as partisan; oral dying decls not relied on.
Defence: Khushal absconding due to excise/liquor case (search Feb 5, 1956).

legal_issues.text: Whether certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) validly granted on question of sufficiency of evidence (fact).
Whether conviction can be based solely on dying declarations without corroboration.
Whether appellant's absconding corroborates dying declarations.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in using absconding as corroboration; absconding due to excise case.
Dying declarations require corroboration per Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of MP; not safe alone.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh AIR 1953 SC 420

petitioner_arguments.text: Eyewitnesses partisan, unreliable; oral dying decls not acted upon.

respondent_arguments.text: Dying declarations consistent, reliable, recorded by public servants promptly.
Absconding of Khushal suspicious, corroborates dying declarations.
No tutoring; deceased fit state; injuries consistent with weapons named.

court_reasoning.text: Certificate under Art.134(1)(c) invalid as based on fact (sufficiency of evidence); dismiss in limine but examine on merits for special leave.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Courts must be vigilant; SC not ordinary court of criminal appeal on facts.

court_reasoning.text: Oral testimony of eyewitnesses PW1,3,4 unreliable/partisan; not used even for corroboration.
No absolute rule requiring corroboration of dying declaration; can be sole basis if reliable after scrutiny.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ram Nath observations obiter; s.32(1) Evidence Act gives special sanctity.

court_reasoning.text: Tests for reliability: opportunity to observe, fit state, consistency, earliest, no tutoring.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Three decls consistent naming Khushal/Tukaram; prompt (within 2.5 hrs); fit certified; light available; injuries match.

court_reasoning.text: Absconding not strong corroboration but not needed; defence excise reason unfounded.

holdings.text: Dying declaration can form sole basis of conviction if court satisfied truthful/reliable after scrutiny; no mandatory corroboration.
Dying declarations here reliable; sustain conviction u/s 302 IPC.
No extenuating circumstances; death sentence upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: Haripada Dey v. State of West Bengal
Narsingh v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: SC not court of criminal appeal on facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh
Sunder Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh
Ram Nath Madhoprasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Obiter on corroboration need; case turned on unreliability.
Dying decl judged like other evidence; no absolute corroboration rule.
Conviction on dying decl alone if truthful.
No hard rule; convict if convinced true.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gulabrao Krishnajee Maratha v. King Emperor

precedents_cited.relevance: PC: Dying decl alone can sustain if believed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Murder charge; alternative with common intention.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Dying decl admissible; no mandatory corr like accomplice.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate of fitness for appeal to SC.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed in limine on invalid certificate but merits examined; conviction u/s 302 IPC and death sentence upheld as dying declarations reliable and sufficient basis.

key_quotes.text: It is settled law that it is not safe to convict an accused person merely on the evidence furnished by a dying declaration without further corroboration...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoted Ram Nath but held obiter.

key_quotes.text: There is no absolute rule of law, or even a rule of prudence... that a dying declaration unless corroborated by other independent evidence, is not fit to be acted upon...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding: Dying decl can be sole basis if reliable.

key_quotes.text: A dying declaration which has been recorded by a competent magistrate... stands on a much higher footing than a dying declaration which depends upon oral testimony.
key_quotes.speaker: court
